data.title: Where 21 of the richest Americans went to college
data.meta_description: Using Forbes' annual "World Billionaire" ranking, INSIDER determined which colleges the wealthiest Americans attended. From siblings that made it big, like Charles and David Koch, to tech innovators such as Bill Gates, here's where some of the richest people in America went to school.
data.text:
While some of the richest people in the US have an Ivy League degree under their belt, others didn't even graduate.

Advertisement

Using Forbes' annual "World Billionaire" ranking, INSIDER determined which colleges the wealthiest Americans attended.

From siblings that made it big, like Charles and David Koch and the children of Walmart founder Sam Walton, to tech innovators such as Bill Gates and Larry Ellison, here's where 21 of the richest Americans went to college.

Advertisement

Jeff Bezos: Princeton University in Princeton, New Jersey

Estimated net worth: $112 billion

Amazon CEO and founder Jeff Bezos â the richest person in the world, according to Forbes' 2018 "World's Billionaires" list â attended Princeton University. He graduated in 1986 with a degree in electrical engineering and computer science.

"When you are 80 years old, and in a quiet moment of reflection narrating only for yourself the most personal version of your life story, the telling that will be the most compact and meaningful will be a series of choices you have made," Bezos told Princeton students in 2010 during the university's Baccalaureate ceremony.

Advertisement

Bill Gates: Harvard University in Cambridge, Massachusetts

Estimated net worth: $90 billion

Bill Gates, who co-founded Microsoft with Paul Allen, went to Harvard University â but dropped out in 1975 before graduating. Degree or not, he's still one of the wealthiest people in the world.

During a Q&A with Harvard students in April, Gates said if he could go back to school, he would choose to study artificial intelligence.

"Today, I would go into software, which today that means going into artificial intelligence," he said, as quoted by CNBC. "Computers still can't read. They cannot take a book of information and, say, pass an AP test on that book. And that's a solvable problem."

Advertisement

Warren Buffett: University of Nebraska in Lincoln, Nebraska

Estimated net worth: $84 billion

Nicknamed the "Oracle of Omaha," investor Warren Buffett attended the University of Nebraska â Lincoln as an undergraduate in the 1940s before pursuing a Master of Science in economics at Columbia University's business school. He transferred to Nebraska from the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School, where he had matriculated at age 16.

Buffett is the CEO of Berkshire Hathaway, which owns numerous companies ranging from Geico to Duracell. According to Forbes, he got an early start in investing, buying his first stock when he was just 11 years old.

Advertisement

Mark Zuckerberg: Harvard University in Cambridge, Massachusetts

Estimated net worth: $71 billion

Like Bill Gates, Mark Zuckerberg â who founded Facebook from his dorm room â is a Harvard dropout. He left in 2005 after his sophomore year.

When Zuckerberg returned to his alma mater to give the commencement address to the class of 2017, he was given an honorary degree.

"I'm here to tell you that finding your purpose isn't enough. The challenge for our generation is to create a world where everyone has a sense of purpose," he told the graduating class.

Advertisement

Abigail Johnson: Hobart and William Smith Colleges in Geneva, New York

Estimated net worth: $15.9 billion

Abigail Johnson â CEO of Fidelity Investments, the largest mutual fund company in the US â graduated from Hobart and William Smith Colleges in 1984 before earning an MBA at Harvard Business School.

Johnson is the granddaughter of Edward Johnson II, who founded Fidelity in 1946.

Advertisement

Charles and David Koch: Massachusetts Institute of Technology in Cambridge, Massachusetts

Estimated net worth: $60 billion each

Industrialists and brothers Charles and David Koch attended the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in the '50s and '60s, respectively. Even more impressive, they each have bachelor's and master's degrees from the famed research university. (Charles has a second master's, to boot.)

While Charles is the CEO of Koch Industries â the second-largest private company in America after Cargill (a producer and distributor of agricultural products) â David was the executive vice president prior to his recent resignation. Koch Industries' subsidiaries produce everything from fertilizer products to water filtration systems.

Advertisement

Larry Ellison: University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign in Champaign, Illinois, and the University of Chicago in Chicago, Illinois

Estimated net worth: $58.5

Larry Ellison dropped out of college twice in the '60s before co-founding the software firm Oracle, of which he's now the chief technology officer (CTO).

Coming from a working-class family of Jewish immigrants in Chicago, he first attended the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign and then the University of Chicago, but didn't complete degrees at either school. He ultimately left the Midwest for California, where he taught himself programming.

"I never took a computer science class in my life. I got a job working as a programmer; I was largely self-taught. I just picked up a book and started programming," Ellison told the Smithsonian Institution in an oral history.

Advertisement

Elon Musk: University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania

Estimated net worth: $19.9 billion

Elon Musk, chairman and CEO of Tesla, first attended Queen's University in Kingston, Ontario, in the early '90s before transferring to the University of Pennsylvania â one of the top producers of billionaire graduates, along with Harvard and Stanford.

Musk, who grew up in South Africa, also co-founded PayPal.

Advertisement

Laurene Powell Jobs: University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania

Estimated net worth: $18.8 billion

Steve Jobs' widow, Laurene Powell Jobs, graduate from the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School in 1985 and has an MBA from the Stanford Graduate School of Business.

Powell Jobs is the founder and chair of the Emerson Collective, an organization that assists students in need through entrepreneurship. In addition, she owns a majority stake of The Atlantic magazine and website.

Advertisement

Michael Bloomberg: Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore, Maryland

Estimated net worth: $50 billion

Former New York City mayor and media company CEO Michael Bloomberg studied engineering at Johns Hopkins in the '60s as an undergraduate before getting an MBA at Harvard Business School.

Bloomberg, who got his start on Wall Street in the 1960s, has donated millions of dollars to Hopkins, including a 2016 gift of $300 million to the School of Public Health.

Advertisement

Larry Page: University of Michigan in Ann Arbor, Michigan

Estimated net worth: $48.8 billion

Larry Page, who co-founded Google with Sergey Brin in 1998, is the CEO of Alphabet, the parent company of the search engine and its other divisions, such as Nest, which makes smart home appliances.

Page earned a bachelor of science in engineering at the University of Michigan in the early '90s before enrolling in a PhD program at Stanford University, where he met Brin.

"It is often easier to make progress on mega-ambitious dreamsâ¦ Since no one else is crazy enough to do it, you have little competition," he said in his 2009 commencement address at Michigan.

Advertisement

Sergey Brin: University of Maryland in College Park, Maryland

Estimated net worth: $47.5 billion

Sergey Brin, who co-founded Google with Larry Page, is the president of the search engine's parent company, Alphabet.

Before meeting Page at Stanford University, Brin attended the University of Maryland, College Park.

"I personally think the early '90s were a tipping point for Computer Science at Maryland. While it was already a stellar program then, it wasn't thought of as such. Sergey's contributions to commercial software â along with those of Gary Flake and others â ultimately sent a clear signal to both the academic and commercial software communities that UMCP's Computer Science program was among the best in the world," Brin's classmate Dave Baggett wrote on Quora.

Advertisement

Jim and Samuel Robson Walton: University of Arkansas in Fayetteville, Arkansas

Estimated net worth: $46.4 billion (Jim Walton) and $46.2 billion (Samuel Robson Walton)

Brothers Jim and S. Robson Walton â two of Walmart founder Sam Walton's children â attended the University of Arkansas.

Jim, who graduated in 1971, is the chairman and CEO of Arvest Bank Group, a financial services company, while S. Robson, a 1966 alumnus who transferred from the College of Wooster, serves as director of Walmart stores.

S. Robson also earned a JD from Columbia University's law school.

Advertisement

Alice Walton: Trinity University in San Antonio, Texas

Estimated net worth: $46 billion

Jim and Samuel Robson's sister, Alice Walton, is an arts patron and philanthropist. She graduated from Trinity University, a liberal arts college in San Antonio, Texas, in 1971.

Instead of working in the family business, Alice used her share of the Walmart fortune to open the Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art in her hometown of Bentonville, Arkansas. In 2015, she was honored with a National Arts Award.

Advertisement

Sheldon Adelson: City College of New York in New York City, New York

Estimated net worth: $38.5 billion

Sheldon Adelson is the chairman and CEO of Las Vegas Sands, America's largest casino company.

Adelson attended the City College of New York, part of the City University of New York (CUNY) system, in the early 1950s but dropped out before graduating.

Advertisement

Steve Ballmer: Harvard University in Cambridge, Massachusetts

Estimated net worth: $38.4 billion

Los Angeles Clippers owner and former Microsoft CEO Steve Ballmer attended Harvard. After he graduated in 1977 with a degree in mathematics and economics, he was accepted into Stanford's MBA program but later dropped out to join Microsoft.

In 2014, Ballmer made a donation to his alma mater to enable the expansion of the university's computer science program.

"CS at Harvard today is small, but excellent," Ballmer said. "It already punches above its weight. With depth in systems, data, machine learning, and artificial intelligence, it is focused on high-impact specialties that are literally changing the world. With this infusion of talent, I believe Harvard will be one of the preeminent, modern CS programs."

Advertisement

Jacqueline Mars: Bryn Mawr College in Bryn Mawr, Pennsylvania

Estimated net worth: $23.6 billion

Jacqueline Mars, who owns one-third of Mars, Incorporated â the world's largest candy manufacturer â graduated from Bryn Mawr College, a women's college located outside Philadelphia and one of the Seven Sisters schools, in 1961. Her brother, John, went to Yale.

Mars worked for the candy company for about 20 years and is also known for her philanthropic work. She serves on the board of multiple organizations, such as the Smithsonian and the National Archives.

Advertisement

Phil Knight: University of Oregon in Eugene, Oregon

Estimated net worth: $29.6 billion

Phil Knight was the chairman of Nike until he retired in 2016. He created the sneaker company with Bill Bowerman, who was his coach when he ran track at the University of Oregon.

After completing his bachelor's in 1959, he received an MBA from the Stanford Graduate School of Business.

In 2016, Knight and his wife donated $500 million to his undergraduate alma mater to fund a science center.

Advertisement

Advertisement

Advertisement

James Simons: Massachusetts Institute of Technology in Cambridge, Massachusetts

Estimated net worth: $20 billion

James Simons founded Renaissance Technologies, a quantitative hedge fund firm. As an undergraduate, he attended the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. After graduating in 1958, he earned a PhD from the University of California, Berkeley.
